author: Potter
text: "I'll be at charges for a looking-glass; And entertain a score or two of tailors." [Richard III]

author: Potter
text: My Dear Freda:

author: Potter
text: Because you are fond of fairytales, and have been ill, I have made you a story all for yourself--a new one that nobody has read before.

author: Potter
text: And the queerest thing about it is--that I heard it in Gloucestershire, and that it is true--at least about the tailor, the waistcoat, and the "No more twist!" _Christmas_

author: Potter
text: In the time of swords and peri wigs and full-skirted coats with flowered lappets--when gentlemen wore ruffles, and gold-laced waistcoats of paduasoy and taffeta--there lived a tailor in Gloucester.

author: Potter
text: He sat in the window of a little shop in Westgate Street, cross-legged on a table from morning till dark.

author: Potter
text: All day long while the light lasted he sewed and snippetted, piecing out his satin, and pompadour, and lutestring; stuffs had strange names, and were very expensive in the days of the Tailor of Gloucester.

author: Potter
text: But although he sewed fine silk for his neighbours, he himself was very, very poor.

author: Potter
text: He cut his coats without waste; according to his embroidered cloth, they were very small ends and snippets that lay about upon the table--"Too narrow breadths for nought--except waistcoats for mice," said the tailor.

author: Potter
text: One bitter cold day near Christmastime the tailor began to make a coat (a coat of cherry- coloured corded silk embroidered with pansies and roses) and a cream- coloured satin waistcoat for the Mayor of Gloucester.

author: Potter
text: The tailor worked and worked, and he talked to himself: "No breadth at all, and cut on the cross; it is no breadth at all; tippets for mice and ribbons for mobs! for mice!" said the Tailor of Gloucester.

author: Potter
text: When the snow-flakes came down against the small leaded window- panes and shut out the light, the tailor had done his day's work; all the silk and satin lay cut out upon the table.

author: Potter
text: There were twelve pieces for the coat and four pieces for the waistcoat; and there were pocket-flaps and cuffs and buttons, all in order.

author: Potter
text: For the lining of the coat there was fine yellow taffeta, and for the button- holes of the waistcoat there was cherry-coloured twist.

author: Potter
text: And everything was ready to sew together in the morning, all measured and sufficient--except that there was wanting just one single skein of cherry-coloured twisted silk.

author: Potter
text: The tailor came out of his shop at dark.

author: Potter
text: No one lived there at nights but little brown mice, and THEY ran in and out without any keys!

author: Potter
text: For behind the wooden wainscots of all the old houses in Gloucester, there are little mouse staircases and secret trap-doors; and the mice run from house to house through those long, narrow passages.

author: Potter
text: But the tailor came out of his shop and shuffled home through the snow.

author: Potter
text: And although it was not a big house, the tailor was so poor he only rented the kitchen.

author: Potter
text: He lived alone with his cat; it was called Simpkin.

author: Potter
text: "Miaw?" said the cat when the tailor opened the door, "miaw?"

author: Potter
text: The tailor replied: "Simpkin, we shall make our fortune, but I am worn to a ravelling.

author: Potter
text: Take this groat (which is our last fourpence), and, Simpkin, take a china pipkin, but a penn'orth of bread, a penn'orth of milk, and a penn'orth of sausages.

author: Potter
text: And oh, Simpkin, with the last penny of our fourpence but me one penn'orth of cherry-coloured silk.

author: Potter
text: But do not lose the last penny of the fourpence, Simpkin, or I am undone and worn to a thread-paper, for I have NO MORE TWIST."

author: Potter
text: Then Simpkin again said "Miaw!" and took the groat and the pipkin, and went out into the dark.

author: Potter
text: The tailor was very tired and beginning to be ill.

author: Potter
text: He sat down by the hearth and talked to himself about that wonderful coat.

author: Potter
text: "I shall make my fortune--to be cut bias--the Mayor of Gloucester is to be married on Christmas Day in the morning, and he hath ordered a coat and an embroidered waistcoat--"

author: Potter
text: Then the tailor started; for suddenly, interrupting him, from the dresser at the other side of the kitchen came a number of little noises--

author: Potter
text: Tip tap, tip tap, tip tap tip!

author: Potter
text: "Now what can that be?" said the Tailor of Gloucester, jumping up from his chair.

author: Potter
text: The tailor crossed the kitchen, and stood quite still beside the dresser, listening, and peering through his spectacles.

author: Potter
text: "This is very peculiar," said the Tailor of Gloucester, and he lifted up the tea-cup which was upside down.

author: Potter
text: Out stepped a little live lady mouse, and made a courtesy to the tailor!

author: Potter
text: Then she hopped away down off the dresser, and under the wainscot.

author: Potter
text: The tailor sat down again by the fire, warming his poor cold hands.

author: Potter
text: But all at once, from the dresser, there came other little noises--

author: Potter
text: Tip tap, tip tap, tip tap tip!

author: Potter
text: "This is passing extraordinary!" said the Tailor of Gloucester, and turned over another tea-cup, which was upside down.

author: Potter
text: Out stepped a little gentleman mouse, and made a bow to the tailor!

author: Potter
text: And out from under tea-cups and from under bowls and basins, stepped other and more little mice, who hopped away down off the dresser and under the wainscot.

author: Potter
text: The tailor sat down, close over the fire, lamenting: "One-and-twenty buttonholes of cherry-coloured silk!

author: Potter
text: To be finished by noon of Saturday: and this is Tuesday evening.

author: Potter
text: Was it right to let loose those mice, undoubtedly the property of Simpkin?

author: Potter
text: Alack, I am undone, for I have no more twist!"

author: Potter
text: The little mice came out again and listened to the tailor; they took notice of the pattern of that wonderful coat.

author: Potter
text: They whispered to one another about the taffeta lining and about little mouse tippets.

author: Potter
text: And then suddenly they all ran away together down the passage behind the wainscot, squeaking and calling to one another as they ran from house to house.

author: Potter
text: Not one mouse was left in the tailor's kitchen when Simpkin came back.

author: Potter
text: He set down the pipkin of milk upon the dresser, and looked suspiciously at the tea-cups.

author: Potter
text: He wanted his supper of little fat mouse!

author: Potter
text: "Simpkin," said the tailor, "where is my TWIST?"

author: Potter
text: But Simpkin hid a little parcel privately in the tea-pot, and spit and growled at the tailor; and if Simpkin had been able to talk, he would have asked: "Where is my MOUSE?"

author: Potter
text: "Alack, I am undone!" said the Tailor of Gloucester, and went sadly to bed.

author: Potter
text: All that night long Simpkin hunted and searched through the kitchen, peeping into cupboards and under the wainscot, and into the tea-pot where he had hidden that twist; but still he found never a mouse!

author: Potter
text: The poor old tailor was very ill with a fever, tossing and turning in his four-post bed; and still in his dreams he mumbled: "No more twist! no more twist!"

author: Potter
text: What should become of the cherry- coloured coat?

author: Potter
text: Who should come to sew it, when the window was barred, and the door was fast locked?

author: Potter
text: Out-of-doors the market folks went trudging through the snow to buy their geese and turkeys, and to bake their Christmas pies; but there would be no dinner for Simpkin and the poor old tailor of Gloucester.

author: Potter
text: The tailor lay ill for three days and nights; and then it was Christmas Eve, and very late at night.

author: Potter
text: And still Simpkin wanted his mice, and mewed as he stood beside the four-post bed.

author: Potter
text: But it is in the old story that all the beasts can talk in the night between Christmas Eve and Christmas Day in the morning (though there are very few folk that can hear them, or know what it is that they say).

author: Potter
text: When the Cathedral clock struck twelve there was an answer--like an echo of the chimes--and Simpkin heard it, and came out of the tailor's door, and wandered about in the snow.

author: Potter
text: From all the roofs and gables and old wooden houses in Gloucester came a thousand merry voices singing the old Christmas rhymes--all the old songs that ever I heard of, and some that I don't know, like Whittington's bells.

author: Potter
text: Under the wooden eaves the starlings and sparrows sang of Christmas pies; the jackdaws woke up in the Cathedral tower; and although it was the middle of the night the throstles and robins sang; and air was quite full of little twittering tunes.

author: Potter
text: But it was all rather provoking to poor hungry Simpkin.

author: Potter
text: From the tailor's ship in Westgate came a glow of light; and when Simpkin crept up to peep in at the window it was full of candles.

author: Potter
text: There was a snippeting of scissors, and snappeting of thread; and little mouse voices sang loudly and gaily:

author: Potter
text: "Four-and-twenty tailors Went to catch a snail, The best man amongst them Durst not touch her tail; She put out her horns Like a little kyloe cow.

author: Potter
text: Run, tailors, run!

author: Potter
text: Or she'll have you all e'en now!"

author: Potter
text: Then without a pause the little mouse voices went on again:

author: Potter
text: "Sieve my lady's oatmeal, Grind my lady's flour, Put it in a chestnut, Let it stand an hour--"

author: Potter
text: "Mew!

author: Potter
text: Mew!" interrupted Simpkin, and he scratched at the door.

author: Potter
text: But the key was under the tailor's pillow; he could not get in.

author: Potter
text: The little mice only laughed, and tried another tune--

author: Potter
text: "Three little mice sat down to spin, Pussy passed by and she peeped in.

author: Potter
text: What are you at, my fine little men?

author: Potter
text: Making coats for gentlemen.

author: Potter
text: Shall I come in and cut off yours threads?

author: Potter
text: Oh, no, Miss Pussy, You'd bite off our heads!"

author: Potter
text: "Mew! scratch! scratch!" scuffled Simpkin on the window-sill; while the little mice inside sprang to their feet, and all began to shout all at once in little twittering voices: "No more twist!

author: Potter
text: No more twist!"

author: Potter
text: And they barred up the window-shutters and shut out Simpkin.

author: Potter
text: Simpkin came away from the shop and went home considering in his mind.

author: Potter
text: He found the poor old tailor without fever, sleeping peacefully.

author: Potter
text: Then Simpkin went on tip-toe and took a little parcel of silk out of the tea-pot; and looked at it in the moonlight; and he felt quite ashamed of his badness compared with those good little mice!

author: Potter
text: When the tailor awoke in the morning, the first thing which he saw, upon the patchwork quilt, was a skein of cherry-coloured twisted silk, and beside his bed stood the repentant Simpkin!

author: Potter
text: The sun was shining on the snow when the tailor got up and dressed, and came out into the street with Simpkin running before him.

author: Potter
text: "Alack," said the tailor, "I have my twist; but no more strength--nor time--than will serve to make me one single buttonhole; for this is Christmas Day in the Morning!

author: Potter
text: The Mayor of Gloucester shall be married by noon--and where is his cherry- coloured coat?"

author: Potter
text: He unlocked the door of the little shop in Westgate Street, and Simpkin ran in, like a cat that expects something.

author: Potter
text: But there was no one there!

author: Potter
text: Not even one little brown mouse!

author: Potter
text: But upon the table--oh joy! the tailor gave a shout--there, where he had left plain cuttings of silk--there lay the most beautiful coat and embroidered satin waistcoat that ever were worn by a Mayor of Gloucester!

author: Potter
text: Everything was finished except just one single cherry-coloured buttonhole, and where that buttonhole was wanting there was pinned a scrap of paper with these words--in little teeny weeny writing--

author: Potter
text: NO MORE TWIST.

author: Potter
text: And from then began the luck of the Tailor of Gloucester; he grew quite stout, and he grew quite rich.

author: Potter
text: He made the most wonderful waistcoats for all the rich merchants of Gloucester, and for all the fine gentlemen of the country round.

author: Potter
text: Never were seen such ruffles, or such embroidered cuffs and lappets!

author: Potter
text: But his buttonholes were the greatest triumph of it all.

author: Potter
text: The stitches of those buttonholes were so neat--SO neat--I wonder how they could be stitched by an old man in spectacles, with crooked old fingers, and a tailor's thimble.

author: Potter
text: The stitches of those buttonholes were so small--SO small--they looked as if they had been made by little mice!
